o: Using HTML tags that convey the meaning of the content (e.g. <article>, <nav>) rather than just presentation

q: Why is Semantic HTML important for SEO?
o: It helps search engines understand the structure and importance of different parts of your content

q: Why is Semantic HTML important for Accessibility?
o: Screen readers use the semantic structure to navigate and read the content meaningfully to users

q: Which tag represents the main content of a document?
Can you have multiple <main> tags on a page?
o: No, there should be only one visible <main> element per page

q: Which tag represents a self-contained composition (like a blog post)?
Which tag represents a generic standalone section of a document?
Which tag represents introductory content (logo, navigation)?
Which tag represents a footer for a section or page?
Which tag represents content aside from the content it is placed in (sidebar)?
What is the difference between <div> and <section>?
o: <div> has no semantic meaning; <section> implies a thematic grouping of content, usually with a heading

q: Which tag represents a figure illustrated (image, diagram) with a caption?
Which tag represents the caption for a <figure>?
Which tag represents a specific time or date?
Which tag represents contact information for the author/owner?
Which heading tag is the most important?
How many <h1> tags should be on a standard page?
o: Usually one, representing the main topic of the page

Which tag represents strong importance (usually bold)?
What is the semantic difference between <i> and <em>?
o: <em> implies emphasis/stress; <i> is for alternate voice/mood (scientific name, foreign term) without implied emphasis

q: What is the semantic difference between <b> and <strong>?
o: <strong> implies importance/seriousness; <b> is stylistically offset (keywords) without extra importance
